title: Part (a)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

A response that states that the economy is in an inflationary gap or that fails to explain why the economy is in a recessionary gap will earn zero points.
descriptions: The response does not state that the economy is in a recessionary gap and/or does not explain that current real output is less than full employment output ( $400 billion < $500 billion ) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4D7C@

The response states that the economy is in a recessionary gap and explains that current real output is less than full employment output ( $400 billion < $500 billion ) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4D7C@

title: Part (b)
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

The response must show appropriate work in order to receive each point.

The response should be consistent with the output gap in part (a).
descriptions: The response does not accurately include any of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes one of the criteria below.
The response accurately includes both of the criteria below.

title: Part (c)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. The response must both state that the increase in government spending is more effective and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that the increase in government spending is more effective in closing the output gap than the decrease in income taxes and/or does not explain that the entire government spending increase goes toward increasing aggregate demand, but only a portion of the increased disposable income (resulting from lower income taxes) is consumed due to the marginal propensity to save. (A response that includes a comparison of the values calculated in part (b) to explain why government spending is more effective in closing the output gap is also acceptable.)

The response states that the increase in government spending is more effective in closing the output gap than the decrease in income taxes and explains that this is because the entire government spending increase goes toward increasing aggregate demand, but only a portion of the increased disposable income (resulting from lower income taxes) is consumed due to the marginal propensity to save. (A response that includes a comparison of the values calculated in part (b) to explain why government spending is more effective in closing the output gap is also acceptable.)

title: Part (d)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response. The response must both state that short-run aggregate supply will increase and explain why in order to receive the point.
descriptions: The response does not state that short-run aggregate supply will increase in the long run and/or does not explain that it will increase because of the decrease in input prices, nominal wages, or inflationary expectations.
The response states that short-run aggregate supply will increase in the long run because of the decrease in input prices, nominal wages, or inflationary expectations.
